Comment: First move out of schemes. I tried this some times, well knowing that d4 comes, and then Bb6 makes me lose a tempo... but I solve the dsb's dev problem, and if ever white wants to play d5, my B would be looking at f7. He can take it, true, but that implies white to exchange Nc3...

Premature is ...Ng4, after o-o white seems fine. But this is the kind of position Tal could win by sactifying two queens... (say, after h3, h5! and this kind of things).
Much better than Nc6, in my view. Opens squares for my dsb and Q, blocksa any N or Bb5 attempt, and prepares to support Nf6 with Nd7.
Finally. I was waiting for it.
Finally. I was waiting for it.
Finally. I was waiting for it.
...or Bb4, being prepared to exchange it. But it is a bad plan.
Expected, also. Not dangerous now to move the Q.
Now I have a chance to castle either Q or K side. I play for fun, and I don't like "even looking positions", if I can avoid them. I have to be smarter. Now, I thought a long time before playing...
Now I have a chance to castle either Q or K side. I play for fun, and I don't like "even looking positions", if I can avoid them. I have to be smarter. Now, I thought a long time before playing...
Probably not holdable against a good player. But...

An innocent plan. I can leave him the B and play for the reason I castled Q side: NxN. And this would have been good enough. But I figured a crazy plan to get something more from the situation, as the pawn d4. I realized that I coud take it, since after QxB, NxN would have got the same result, but with white dislocated, wide opened in the center, ect. etc. I didn't want to allow NxB+ plainly.
White interposes a move, and I dont' want to add the exchange to the bargain, so I took... what do you think is the right take?
White interposes a move, and I dont' want to add the exchange to the bargain, so I took... what do you think is the right take?
...maybe, opening a valuable column against white!
Finally, white decides to take.
? I take back winning a tempo and grabbing control of the white squares white's lsb can reach. But I lost of sight of a simple but dangerous fact.
Uh-oh. I have to cope with... Nb6! How?
Only saving move!
After RxN, the threat is still "on"!
I calculated that I had to force the situation before white does. If Qa8+, Nb8 and all I can see for white are exchanges. At least, I hoped so!
Bxd7, Qa8+, ...Qb8, Nb6+ black is dead, so I preferred to give up the exchange...
Bxd7, Qa8+, ...Qb8, Nb6+ black is dead, so I preferred to give up the exchange...
...which I am not doing, actually! Can you see why?
...which I am not doing, actually! Can you see why?
Uh-oh! Had to perform the Qa8+...Qb8, QxQ+...KxQ, NxR sequence before, and this small step meant the loss of the game for him.
